body:
[`tokenize` is a standard library module](https://docs.python.org/2/library/tokenize.html) we use. If, when we try to import that, Python finds a different module instead, it dies. That's true of any module we import.

There are some ways we could get round this for things in the current working directory, but:
1. They're hackish, and would either require special-casing Python or forcing other kernels to jump through extra hoops for no good reason.
2. You still wouldn't be able to use your `tokenize` (or whatever) as a module, because Python expects each module name to be used only once.
3. Naming Python files like standard library modules is a bad idea anyway.

So sorry, you just need to rename your file.

Ugh Python always takes the good names
On Tue, May 19, 2015 at 6:27 PM Thomas Kluyver notifications@github.com
wrote:

> 2. You still wouldn't be able to use your tokenize (or whatever) as a
